note.p: This is a letter from Thomas B. Garvey, a member of the Board of Guardians Council, to Robert Chalmers (1858-1938), the under-secretary of Ireland. It discusses a Board of Guardians meeting held in Kerry, enclosing a cutting regarding the meeting. Garvey writes that he made a resolution for the board to condemn the actions of the rebels during the 1916 Rising, and that all but one person supported the resolution. Garvey goes on to write that Michael Keating, a man he describes as an extreme Sinn Feiner, proposed to rescind the resolution. When an objection was made by Garvey turmoil and disorder ensued. Robert Chalmers became under-secretary for a brief period following the resignation of Matthew Nathan (1862-1939), who relinquished his position due to his administration's failure to contain the 1916 Rising.

text.body:
Bridge Street Caherciveen 3/6/16 To the Right Honourable Sir R. Chalmers Under - Secretary Dublin Castle Sir
Referring to my letter of 31st ult, I beg to
submit for your information a cutting from the Killarney Echo
of 20th ult., containing a report of the proceedings of the Board
of Guardians and District Council of 17th ult. There were fifteen
Councillors present on the occasion, and a resolution which I pro
posed condemning the recent rebellion in Dublin was passed
with one dissenting voice. A notice to rescind that resolution
on that day a fortnight was handed in by Councillor Michael
Keating who is an extreme Sinn Feiner. He is a small
farmer, and he has five nieces teaching schools under
the National Board.
I also enclose a cutting from the Killarney Echo of
this date giving a report of the proceedings of the Council
on 31st ult. Mr Keating's motion to rescind my resolution
was carried by 7 votes to 3. There were eleven Councillors
present at that meeting. One did not vote. A number of
the Councillors who were present at the meeting of the 17th
ult., were I have been informed , threatened by the Sinn
Fein members not to attend. When I got up to move
the rejection of Mr Keating's motion the Sinn Fein
members created an unprecedented scene of tumult and
disorder. The outburst was apparently premeditated. I am Sir Your Obedient Servant, T.B. Garvey
R.D.C. Await report
from R. M. m
file 11413/5
E O F
5/6/16
CILL AIRNE
ECHO
916. May 20th 1916 price - one penny. CAHERCIVEEN GUARDIANS
AND COUNCIL.
THE REBELLION.
HEATED DISCUSSION.
GERMAN GOLD.
£2,500 FOR CAHERCIVEEN.
MEMBER'S ALLEGATION.
Caherciveen , Wednesday Night.
The usual fortnightly meeting of the
Caherciveen Board of Guardians and
Rural District Council was held to-day.
Mr Michael Courtney, Vice-Chair-
man presided.
The other members present were:—
Messrs. John A. O'Sullivan, Thomas
Garvey, Daniel O'Sullivan, Thomas
Harty, J. P. ; John P. O'Sullivan,
Timothy D. McCarthy, Michl. Keating,
Patrick Walsh, William Murphy, Jolm
J. O'Sullivan, Patrick O'Sullivan, (
Upper), James Curran, Martin
O'Connor, Patrick O'Sullivan ( Canuig ),
and Michael Mangan.
Whitewashing, etc.
Mr Thomas C. Fitzgerald ( Clerk )
stated that some whitewashing was re-
quisite to be effected in the Workhouse
and also the Clerk's office, and the
Boardroom required to be cleansed
Mr John P O'Sullivan suggested
that the cleansing of the Clerk's office
and the Boardroom be adjourned until
after the war.
Mr McCarthy agreed.
Clerk — They may be right for you,
Mr O'Sullivan but not for me,
has to spend the days here. There was
nothing done to them for the last 12
months.
Mr John A O'Sullivan — I propose
that the whitewashing, etc., in the
Workhouse and Clerk's office, board-
room be done.
Mr Walsh — I second it
Mr. John P. O'Sullivan proposed a
resolution that the work be not done.
The Chairman voted for Mr. John A.
O'Sullivan's proposition, which was
therefore carried by a majority of one
vote.
The Election of a Medical Officer.
This being the day fixed for the elec-
tion of a Medical Officer for the
Alexander O' Driscoll, there was only
one applicant for the position, viz —
Dr T. O' Driscoll, Valentia.
The Clerk read the following letter
relative to the above proposed elec-
tion:—
Local Government Board,
Dublin , 9th May 1916.
Sir,— With reference to an entry in
the minutes of proceedings of Caher-
civeen Union on the 19th ultimo, the
Local Government Board
call attention to their circular letter of
the 25th ult., and stated that the ques-
ion of filling up the vacant Medical
Officership of Valentia should be post
posed until after the termination of
the war. — I am, sir, your obedient
servant,
J. E. DEVLIN, Asst. Sec.
Mr. John A. O'Sullivan — The
people of Valentia want a doctor. There
is no other doctor to take up the posi-
tion but the applicant. He is em-
ployed by the Valentia Cable Company
and is the soldiers' doctor in Valentia.
I propose that Dr. T. O'Driscoll be
appointed.
Mr. Walsh — I second it.
Mr. John P. O'Sullivan — The Val-
entia people want a doctor as well as
any other people.
The proposition was adopted.
Dr. O'Driscoll returned thanks.
A Letter.
The Clerk read the following: —
Local Government Board,
Dublin, 16th May, 1916.
Sir, — I am directed by the local Go-
vernment Board for Ireland to for-
ward to be laid before the Board of
Guardians of Caherciveen Union, the
accompanying copy of a communication
which they have received from Mr. T.
Garvey, P.L.G relating to a man
named Callaghan, an inmate of the
Workhouse, and I am to request that
the Board may be furnished with the
observations of the Guardians thereon.
— I am, sir, your obedient servant,
A. R. BARLAS
The transmitted Letter.
Caherciveen, 29th April, 1916.
To the Secretary, L. G. B.
Dublin
Sir, — An order for the discharge of
an able-bodied pauper named John Cal-
laghan was made by the Guardians
here in 1914, but he was re-admitted
shortly afterwards without their autho
rity. It is quite manifest that the
Master took upon himself this respon
sibility, and if he is allowed to usurp
powers which he does not possess, dis
cipline cannot be maintained. Callag
han is not a native of this Union. He
is I understand, a native of County
Clare. He is a sound, healthy, vig-
porous man, and apparently fit for mili-
tary service. It is nothing short of a
scandal to keep a man of this class in
the Workhouse at the expense of the
ratepayers. He is a painter by trade
and could at present earn from £2 to
£3 per week in England or Scotland.
A discussion took place on this
matter at the meeting of the Guard-
ians held at Caherciveen on the 19th
inst., but no order was made. The
Master admitted that Callaghan is
very useful to him in the way of brush
ing his rooms, cooking his food, and
painting. I am not aware that the
Local Government Board or the Guard
ians have made any provision for pro-
curing a butler for the Master. This
certainly is an innovation in Work-
house administration. Please bring
this report under the notice of A. P.
Delaney. Esq. Local Government Board
Inspector, so that he may deal with
the matter on his next inspection. I
enclose a cutting from the Killarney
Echo of the 29th inst. giving parti-
culars of the discussion on the 19th
inst. by the Guardians in reference to
Callaghan. — Yours faithfully
T. GARVEY P. L. G.
Mr. McCarthy — The Workhouse
Master says he is very useful.
Master — He is not a very healthy
man, an his sight is weak. He does a
good deal of painting in the house.
He is not my butler, but he is useful
Mr Garvey — He was discharged
Master — He was discharged in my
absence while I was on leave.
Mr Garvey — I know you were on
leave at the time.
Mr John A. O' Sullivan — He was dis-
charged and it was at my proposition
he was kept the last day, and Mr
Garvey did not object.
Mr Garvey — The minutes of the
meeting in June, 1914, will show the
order of his discharge from the Work-
house.
Mr. John A. O'Sullivan — Is an inmate
of the workhouse supposed to attend or
do business for the officers of the Work-
house?
Clerk — There is no such arrangement
made that the inmates should be re-
quired to do work for the officers of the
house.
After some further discussion it was
agreed to allow Callaghan in the house
Mr Garvey dissenting.
THE RECENT INSURRECTION
Mr Garvey proposed the following re-
solution "That we express our horror and
of the Sinn Fein rebellion in
Dublin and elsewhere in Ireland, and
view with indignation the appalling loss
of life and destruction of valuable pro
perty. That we renew implicit confidence
in the constitutional policy of Mr John
E. Redmond and the Irish Party. That
